docs.lead_paragraph: Medicare may cover advance care planning that was once decried as “death panels,” and some private insurers are not waiting for the political process.

headline.main: Coverage for End-of-Life Talks Gaining Ground
headline.print_headline: Coverage for End-of-Life Talks Gaining Ground

docs.abstract: Medicare may begin covering end-of-life care consultations by doctors, type of planning once derided as 'death panels,' if it approves recommendation from the American Medical Assn; interest in consultations has risen along with the number of aging Americans, and many private insurers have already begun reimbursing doctors for them.
docs.snippet: Medicare may cover advance care planning that was once decried as “death panels,” and some private insurers are not waiting for the political process.

keywords.value: Living Wills and Health Care Proxies
keywords.name: subject

keywords.value: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: The latest jerry-built effort to destroy the Affordable Care Act is facing likely defeat before a full federal appeals court in the District of Columbia.

headline.main: Endless Assault on Health Care Reform
headline.print_headline: Endless Assault on Health Care Reform

docs.abstract: Editorial criticizes latest effort to dismantle Affordable Care Act, which has been helped by three-judge panel of federal appeals court in District of Columbia, who ruled that tax-credit subsidies are allowed only for those buying insurance on state health exchange; expresses hope that full appeals court will rehear the case so that it does not go to Supreme Court.
docs.snippet: The latest jerry-built effort to destroy the Affordable Care Act is facing likely defeat before a full federal appeals court in the District of Columbia.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: Trying to unravel a health plan’s policy on prescription costs offers fresh evidence of just how confusing the American health care system really is.

headline.main: Baby’s Drug Co-Pay Jumps, and a Health Reporter Is Stumped
headline.print_headline: Those Rising Co-Payments for Prescription Drugs

docs.abstract: The Upshot column; frustrations of consumers attempting to make sense of health plan policies on prescription costs highlights how difficult and confusing American health care system can be to navigate; patients are paying increasing share of costs, but have insufficient information available to them to make informed health care decisions.
docs.snippet: Trying to unravel a health plan’s policy on prescription costs offers fresh evidence of just how confusing the American health care system really is.

docs.lead_paragraph: Some activists like Rebecca Gomperts are now imagining the unthinkable: a future where most abortions happen at home.

headline.main: The Dawn of the Post-Clinic Abortion

docs.abstract: Doctor and activist Rebecca Gomperts, who started support service Women on Web, has designed program based on idea of providing abortions without direct contact with doctor in countries where abortions are illegal or highly restricted; idea is based on medical abortion, in which pills induce miscarriages in first trimester, and is galvanizing abortion activists even in the United States.
docs.snippet: Some activists like Rebecca Gomperts are now imagining the unthinkable: a future where most abortions happen at home.

docs.lead_paragraph: A lifelong race to become the Senate majority leader comes down to whether he can make one last sprint.

headline.main: Mitch McConnell Is Headed Down the Stretch

docs.abstract: Race for Kentucky Senate seat between Republican Sen Mitch McConnell and Democrat Alison Lundergan Grimes has become magnet for contributions from large outside 'super PACs' and wealthy individual donors; at stake is not only McConnell's position in the Senate, but also his long-held dream of being Senate majority leader.
docs.snippet: A lifelong race to become the Senate majority leader comes down to whether he can make one last sprint.

docs.lead_paragraph: If you got health coverage through President Barack Obama's law this year, you'll need a new form from your insurance exchange before you can file your tax return next spring.

headline.main: Tax Forms Could Pose Challenge for HealthCare.gov
headline.print_headline: Tax Forms Could Pose Challenge for HealthCare.gov

docs.snippet: If you got health coverage through President Barack Obama's law this year, you'll need a new form from your insurance exchange before you can file your tax return next spring.

docs.lead_paragraph: Since the government is spending less on Medicare, it seemed like a good idea to spend less on a much-loved cocktail.
docs.snippet: Since the government is spending less on Medicare, it seemed like a good idea to spend less on a much-loved cocktail.

docs.lead_paragraph: More retired Americans are getting rid of their homes and traveling, with 360,000 of them receiving Social Security benefits at foreign addresses.

headline.main: Increasingly, Retirees Dump Their Possessions and Hit the Road
headline.print_headline: Increasingly, Retirees Dump Their Possessions and Hit the Road

docs.abstract: Retiring column; more retired Americans are choosing a life of travel over a life of tending to possessions; some 360,000 Americans received Social Security benefits at foreign addresses in 2013, about 48 percent more than 10 years earlier; many say selling their homes and dumping their possessions to travel light, while nerve-wracking at first, can be hugely liberating.
docs.snippet: More retired Americans are getting rid of their homes and traveling, with 360,000 of them receiving Social Security benefits at foreign addresses.

docs.lead_paragraph: The latest banks are small enough to fit in the palm of your hand.

headline.main: Startups Offer Banking for Smartphone Users
headline.print_headline: Startups Offer Banking for Smartphone Users

docs.snippet: The latest banks are small enough to fit in the palm of your hand.

docs.lead_paragraph: The man who masterminded an $800 million insurance scam that fleeced tens of thousands of investors in one of Florida's all-time largest fraud schemes was sentenced Friday to 20 years in prison.

headline.main: Chief in $800M Fraud Gets 20 Years Prison
headline.print_headline: Chief in $800M Fraud Gets 20 Years Prison

docs.snippet: The man who masterminded an $800 million insurance scam that fleeced tens of thousands of investors in one of Florida's all-time largest fraud schemes was sentenced Friday to 20 years in prison.
